fields.label_text:
DURGA AS MAHISASURAMARDINI
Metamorphosed impure limestone
Hassan district, Karnataka, Deccan
Hoysala style, mid-13th century

The goddess Durga, the sakti or female energy of Siva, in her ferocious form as the slayer of the buffalo demon Mahisasura. Durga is represented in her eight-armed aspect, wielding the sacred weapons used against the forces of Evil. The demon is seen emerging from his buffalo guise as Durga's trident (trisula) pierces his body. The Hoysalas established their capital at Halebid early in the 11th century and endowed many major temples in southern Karnataka. Their flamboyant sculptural style derived from the late Calyuka traditions and flourished throughout the 12th and 13th centuries. This sculpture and the accompanying Surya (IS 76-1965) were presented to the seventh Viscount Powerscourt in 1861. Their provenance is unrecorded but close parallels can be seen in the sculptures at Sadasiva Temple, Nuggihalli, south-east of Halebid.

IS 77-1965

fields.descriptive_line: Durga Mahisasuramardini, limestone, southern Karnataka, India, mid-13th century

fields.name: : L’escultura en els temples indis: l’art de la devocio
India: The Art of the Temple, Shanghai  Museum

fields.physical_description: The goddess is eight-armed and holds the bana, chakra, khadga and trisula in her right arms and the dhanus, ghanta and khetaka in her upper left hands, pressing Mahesha's head with the remaining hand. The demon is pierced by Durga's trident as he emerges from the dying buffalo form. Two other asuras are shown- one is pieced by an arrow and the other receives a thrust from Durga's sword. The goddess wears elaborate ornaments including a ratna mukuta, karas, yajna pavita, katibandha, makara kindalas and rings, bracelets, armlets and anklets. Behind the group is makara torana with kirttimukha at the top.
fields.dimensions: Height: 143 cm, Width: 73.5 cm, Depth: 35.5 cm, Weight: 450 kg
fields.title: Durga Mahisasuramardini
fields.label:
DURGA AS MAHISASURAMARDINI
Metamorphosed impure limestone
Hassan district, Karnataka, Deccan
Hoysala style, mid-13th century

The goddess Durga, the sakti or female energy of Siva, in her ferocious form as the slayer of the buffalo demon Mahisasura. Durga is represented in her eight-armed aspect, wielding the sacred weapons used against the forces of Evil. The demon is seen emerging from his buffalo guise as Durga's trident (trisula) pierces his body. The Hoysalas established their capital at Halebid early in the 11th century and endowed many major temples in southern Karnataka. Their flamboyant sculptural style derived from the late Calyuka traditions and flourished throughout the 12th and 13th centuries. This sculpture and the accompanying Surya (IS 76-1965) were presented to the seventh Viscount Powerscourt in 1861. Their provenance is unrecorded but close parallels can be seen in the sculptures at Sadasiva Temple, Nuggihalli, south-east of Halebid.

IS 77-1965 [1988-2007]

fields.name: South and South East Asian Collection

fields.location: South-East Asia, room 47b, case BNC, shelf 4
fields.public_access_description:
The goddess Durga, the sakti or female energy of Siva, in her ferocious form as the slayer of the buffalo demon Mahisa. Durga is represented in her eight-armed aspect, wielding the sacred weapons used against the forces of evil. The demon is seen emerging from his buffalo guise as Durga’s trisula (trident) pierces his body. The goddess is eight-armed and holds the supernatural weapons of the gods, notably the bana, chakra, khadga and trisula in her right arms and the dhanus, ghanta and khetaka in her upper left hands, pressing Mahisa's head with the remaining hand. The demon is pierced by Durga's trident as he emerges from the dying buffalo form. Two other demons (asuras) are shown - one is pierced by an arrow and the other receives a thrust from Durga's sword. The goddess wears elaborate ornaments including a ratna mukuta, karas, yajna pavita, katibandha, makara kindalas and rings, bracelets, armlets and anklets. Behind the group is makara torana with kirttimukha at the top.

The Hoysalas established their capital at Halebid early in the 11th century and endowed many major temples in southern Karnataka. Their flamboyant sculptural style derived from the late Calyuka traditions and flourished throughout the 12th and 13th centuries. This sculpture was presented to the seventh Viscount Powerscourt whilst in Karnataka in 1861. The precise provenance of this sculpture is not recorded but close parallels can be seen in the sculptures at Sadasiva Temple, Nuggihalli, southeast of Halebid.
fields.exhibition_history:
India: The Art of the Temple, Shanghai  Museum (04/08/2010-14/11/2010)
: L’escultura en els temples indis: l’art de la devocio (CaixaForum, Barcelona 27/07/2007-18/11/2007)
fields.bibliography: Viscount Powerscourt, K.P., P.C. A Description and History of Powerscourt , Mitchell and Hughes, London, 1903 Guy, John,Indian Temple Sculpture, London, V & A Publication, 2007, p.159,pl.180. ISBN 9781851775095. Guy, John (ed.). L’Escultura en els Temples Indis: L’Art de la Devocio, Barcelona : Fundacio ‘La Caixa’, 2007. p.111, cat.71. ISBN 9788476649466 Willis, M. (ed.). India: the Art of the Temple. Shanghai : Shanghai Museum, 2010. 254p, ill. ISBN 978-7-5479-0092-5. Cat. 2:50, pp. 202-3. Text is in Chinese. The original text submitted in English reads: 2: 50 Durga Metamorphosed limestone; 143 cm high India, South, KarNaTaka, Mysore region, mid-13th century CE Victoria and Albert Museum IS.77-1965 2: 51 Sculpture of Durga Terracotta; 17.5 cm high Indian, North, 7th century CE Victoria and Albert Museum IS.71-1986, given by Mary and Douglas Barrett Durga, the goddess represented in these two sculptures, is one of the most commonly depicted of any form of the goddess in India. In her role as Durga Mahishasuramardini, ‘slayer of the demon Mahisha’, Durga saves the male gods and the universe from defeat. The worship of Durga images can be traced as far back as the Kushan period (1st century CE – 320 CE), with surviving images being found at Mathura in North India dating to this period. The first textual accounts of Durga killing the buffalo demon are later, among them the Devibhagavata PuraNa (5th to 7th century CE) and the Devimahatmya, provisionally dated to the 8th century. In these texts, her independent and fierce nature is clearly apparent. Although often considered a form of Siva’s consort Parvati, Durga – the inaccessible - is rarely depicted in a domestic setting, or even with a male consort. Instead Durga is typically realised as a dynamic warrior goddess, defeating all before her. Both sculptures represent the final moment of the battle between Durga and Mahisha, a powerful demon, who takes the form of a buffalo and is invincible to all but a woman. Durga, however, was created from the fierce energy of the male deities and endowed with their weapons. Spurning his offers of marriage, Durga finally slays the shape-shifting Mahisha by cutting off his buffalo head and striking the emerging demon with a trident given to her by Siva. The small terracotta image was probably made for a small domestic or wayside shrine, whereas the larger stone example came from a temple. Both show Durga towering over the other figures, with – especially in the later sculpture - a calm, detached expression, belying any connection with the violent events taking place. The terracotta plaque, made at a time before the iconography of the episode had fully crystallised, shows a four-armed Durga killing the buffalo with her trident, while pressing its neck down with her foot and lifting it by the tail. Her upper hands hold a bell and an unidentified weapon. The buffalo appears to be excreting in death, a touch of sordid realism. In the 13th-century sculpture, Mahisha has resumed his human form and rises out of the buffalo’s hide, only to be speared by Durga. Her multiple arms surround her, holding a selection of weapons and framing the central figure. The lavish embellishment of this sculpture, such as the scrolling decoration in the arched surround and the heavy jewellery she wears, is typical of the HoysaLa dynasty (11th-14th centuries), generous patrons of the arts who ruled much of what is now KarNaTaka. The worship of Durga is still a major part of the Hindu festival calendar, with a large series of rituals being held in her name. Durga Puja, held in the autumn months, involves the creation of large images of the goddess vanquishing the demon. These images are worshipped throughout the festival, which culminates in the submergence of the images in nearby rivers, lakes, ponds or tanks. Cam Sharp Jones and Nick Barnard
fields.history_note: Purchased in 1965 from Mrs G. Slazenger, the owner of the Powerscourt Estate in County Wicklow, Ireland. The Slazenger family purchased the Powerscourt Estate from the Wingfield family in 1961. The 7th Viscount Powerscourt  (1836-1904) described in his history of the house how he acquired two pieces of Indian sculpture while on a sporting tour in the state of Mysore in 1861. He relates how he asked Captain Johnston, who accompanied him on this tour and was at the time the Commissioner of Irrigation for Mysore, 'to get me a specimen or two of these beautiful works of art and he sent me these two [IS.76 and 77-1965, Surya and Durga] saying that he had persuaded the Brahmin in charge of the temple to allow them to be taken away'. Lord Powerscourt thought that they probably came from Halebid, but their provenance remained unrecorded. John Guy recognised close parallels with the sculptures at Sadsiva Temple, Nuggihalli, south-east of Halebid.
fields.production_note: Hassan district, southern Karnataka, Deccan, India
fields.historical_context_note: The goddess Durga, the sakti or female energy of Siva, in her ferocious form as the slayer of the buffalo demon Mahisasura. Durga is represented in her eight armed aspect, wielding the sacred weapons used against the forces of evil. The demon is seen emerging from his buffalo guise as Durgas trident (trisula) pierces his body. The Hoysalas established their capital at Halebid early in the 11th century and endowed many major temples in southern Karnataka. Their flamboyant sculptural style derived from the late Calyuka traditions and flourished throughout the 12th and 13th centuries.
